newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-RBA says any CPI overstatement less than US.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-RBA says any CPI overstatement less than US.

text.p: Reserve Bank of Australia governor Ian Macfarlane said on Thursday he believed any overstatement of inflation in Australia's official data was a fair bit less than the 1.1 percent estimated as the overstatement in the United States.

"There is a tiny little bit of overstatement, but I doubt that it has implications for monetary policy," he told a parliamentary committee when asked about the level of overstatement in Australia's consumer price index data.
Macfarlane was asked by former Labor Treasurer Ralph Willis how large the overstatement was in Australia and if it had any implications for monetary policy.
Willis referred to the report on the overstatement of inflation in the United States by Stanford University economist Michael Boskin.
Boskin estimated that the U.S. CPI overstated inflation by 1.1 percent.
Macfarlane said Boskin's 1.1 percent estimate was controversial and many there estimated as lower.
He said the situation in the United States was different from that in Australia because it did not change its basket of CPI goods as often as Australia.
Macfarlane said any overestimate of inflation would have more implications for fiscal policy, because many benefits are indexed to inflation through the CPI.
